messageBody:
#: by Kent Beck's words the mind was *winged* :#
> Alexandru,
>
> It wasn't your blog I was talking about. You mention several features of
> JUnit 3.x as new that will be part of JUnit 4 only for backward
> compatibility. We are moving away from the composite structure
> (Test/TestCase/TestSuite) because it makes writing runners difficult and it
> doesn't seem to be used much.

Sorry Kent but I am missing what old features I was miss-interpretting. Please let me know I and I
will fix the entry.

cheers,
:alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|

We will build in the most-used decorators to
> the test runner. We would love to figure out a way to make the runner
> pluggable, but so far we haven't been able to do so. Our philosophy is to
> choose simplicity over power when the two conflict.
>
> Take care,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

>> Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4
>>
>>
>> I am sorry this got to you in the wrong form.
>> Please see it by yourself:
>> http://themindstorms.blogspot.com/2005/06/junit-40.html.
>>
>> I was doing a feature by feature comparison. And that todo
>> list was part of the CVS (and was talking
>> about RC and final version - so I haven't got reasons to
>> believe it was old/deprecated).
>>
>> hope this clears out my intention,
>> :alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
>>
>> > The theme of JUnit 4 is to encourage more developers to
>> write more tests by
>> > further simplifying JUnit. To this end, we have followed
>> NUnit's lead in
>> > identifying tests by annotation instead of subclassing and naming
>> > conventions. Tests can now live in any class. Tell JUnit
>> they are there with
>> > the @Test annotation:
>> > @Test public void basicTransaction() {...
>> >
>> > The assertion methods are in an Assert class which is most
>> easily used
>> > through static import:
>> > import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
>> > ...
>> > @Test public void example() {...assertEquals(2, 2);...}
>> >
>> > Set up and tear down are handled with the @Before and
>> @After annotations.
>> > You can have as many @Befores and @Afters as you need.
>> Inherited @Befores
>> > are executed before @Befores in subclasses and inherited @Afters are
>> > executed after @Afters in subclasses.
>> >
>> > Shared setup is handled by @BeforeClass and @AfterClass.
>> Methods with these
>> > annotations are executed once before (respectively after)
>> all the tests in
>> > the class run.
>> >
>> > @Ignore causes a test not to be run, but it is reported as ignored.
>> >
>> > @Test takes two optional parameters. A test annotated
>> @Test(timeout=100)
>> > will fail if the test takes longer than 100 milliseconds to
>> complete. A test
>> > annotated @Test(expected=NullPointerException.class) will fail if a
>> > NullPointerException is not thrown and succeed if a
>> NullPointerException is
>> > thrown.
>> >
>> > Preserving existing investment in tests has taken nearly half of our
>> > development effort. JUnit 4 is forward and backward
>> compatible. You can run
>> > older tests with the JUnit 4 test runner by passing them to
>> the runner. You
>> > can run JUnit 4 tests with older test runners by wrapping
>> the JUnit 4 test
>> > class in a compatibility class. The following method in a
>> JUnit 4 test class
>> > causes it to run correctly with the Eclipse test runner.
>> > public static junit.framework.Test suite() {
>> > return new JUnit4TestAdapter(AssertionTest.class);
>> > }
>> >
>> > JUnit 4's command line interface can be invoked with:
>> > java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore Test1 Test2
>> >
>> > The same interface can be invoked programmatically with:
>> > JUnitCore.run(Test1.class, Test2.class);
>> >
>> > If you want to know more about the details of JUnit 4, you
>> can browse the
>> > tests in org.junit.tests.*.
>> >
>> > Erich and I will be participating on the JUnit lists to
>> discuss further
>> > simplification of JUnit 4, integration with test runners,
>> and experiences
>> > using it. Our experience with it (most of the tests were
>> written JUnit 4
>> > style) has been very positive. The complexity of JUnit 3.x
>> is like a tiny
>> > pebble in a shoe. It doesn't seem like much until it is gone.
>> >
>> > Good testing,
>> >
>> > Kent Beck
